ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a much greater understanding of the International Phonetic Alphabet, theoretical models for understanding vowel and consonant contrasts (i.e. Motor Theory, Perturbation Theory, Source Filter Theory), sound change, sociophonetics, language acquisition, speech perception, spectrogram and waveform analysis, and the anatomical processes that are involved in speech and audition.
I learned so much about how humans produce speech sounds and how the world's languages vary in their phonetic inventories.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: the material was really interesting, and I loved how Professor Shaw used phonetic studies to connect the concepts we were learning to the way languages work in real life. Phonetics can often seem complicated and a little convoluted, but I felt like Shaw did a good job of finding clear ways of explaining things. I felt like I had a lot of aha moments in class. Weaknesses: so there were like nine people in this class, and it was kind of taught at times as if it was a big lecture. I understand the impetuswe had a lot of material to coverbut at the same time I felt like it was sometimes hard to stay focused, and I wanted more opportunities for group discussion/class participation. Like the day we got to determine whether we produced a bunched or retroflex rhotic using an ultrasound that Professor Shaw had brought in was probably my favorite day of the semester. Also, it seemed a little unnecessary to have a final project and then a final final only four days later.

The material is very interesting and its fun to explore the speech sounds that you might've heard in other languages but not known how to reproduce. The lectures can sometimes be a little boring; the days when there was more participation were much more engaging.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend! Material is really interesting, and the language project is a cool opportunity to apply what you've learned throughout the semester to the creation of a linguistic grammar. Just know what you're getting yourself into. You will be expected to learn to pronounce a large number of the world's consonants and vowels, including, but not limited to: unrounded back vowels, velaric ingressive consonants, pharyngeal fricatives, and bilabial approximants. You will also be expected to work with a speaker of a language you're unfamiliar with and spend several hours recording enough individual words and phrases to create a full inventory of the phonemes of the language. And you will be expected to painstakingly construct illustrative diagrams in Praat. Many times. Many, many times.

Absolutely! Every linguistics major should take Phonetics I. So should anyone who's interested in accents, foreign languages, and even things like choral singing. Phonetics has a lot of applications and it was really cool to learn this material.
